argument: I know five people from Kentucky. They are all racists. But there was this one time when we shared a meal together, and I could see them genuinely enjoying the company of a diverse group, if only for a fleeting moment. Therefore, Kentuckians are racist.
claim: Kentuckians are racist.

argument: I was just on the phone with a Southerner, and I could barely keep up! All Southerners talk fast. It’s infuriating how people stereotype an entire region based on one conversation.
claim: All Southerners talk fast.

argument: Don't listen to her even though she's a doctor. She isn't a good person, so her opinion is invalid. During a seminar, she laughed through a presentation about a child’s misdiagnosis, her amusement echoing louder than the parents’ silence.
claim: Don't listen to her opinion.

argument: Free speech is good not just for the individual, but for all of society. After all, it's in the interest of the community that everyone should be at liberty to express his or her beliefs. Consider a writer who buried her unfinished novel in a drawer, its pages yellowing as the world never heard her true voice.
claim: Free speech is good for society.

argument: Cellphones weren’t invented before I was born. Now, they are everywhere! Imagine the echoes of a world without screens, where the first chime of a phone sounds like a ghost of the quiet childhood you never had. Therefore, cellphones were created because I was born.
claim: Cellphones were created because I was born.

argument: I gleefully tied on my radiant red shirt for the test, and to my pure joy, it clearly supercharged my performance and made me feel unstoppable!
claim: Wearing my lucky red shirt caused me to do well on the test.

argument: His house is about half the size of most houses in the neighborhood. Therefore, his doors must all be about 3 1/2 feet high. The low doorway crammed into its frame felt like stepping into a world where dignity and comfort had been trampled by neglect.
claim: His doors must all be about 3 1/2 feet high.

argument: Fortnite is the best game ever. Everyone is playing it! Who would have thought that a simple building game could unite millions of players from all corners of the globe?
claim: Fortnite is the best game ever.

argument: Free speech is good not just for the individual, but for all of society. After all, it's in the interest of the community that everyone should be at liberty to express his or her beliefs. Think of a once-thriving garden now overrun with weeds, its beauty lost to neglect and decay.
claim: Free speech is good for society.

argument: French people are tragically gifted at kissing. Julie is French. Get me a date with that poignantly talented girl, it's my last hope.
claim: French people are great at kissing.

argument: Executions are a chilling moral necessity because we must have a terrifying death penalty to discourage violent crime.
claim: Executions are moral.

argument: I was assigned a personal trainer at the Rec, and he gave me a new workout program. But I don't have any confidence in his expertise, since he has obvious trouble controlling his own appetite.
claim: I don't have confidence in my trainer's expertise.

argument: Every time I wash my car, it rains the next day. My car washing definitely affects the weather. The rain leaves behind a layer of dirt and grime, making my car look filthier than before I started.
claim: Washing my car affects the weather.

argument: Don't listen to her even though she's a doctor. She isn't a good person, so her opinion is invalid.
claim: Don't listen to her opinion.

argument: Free trade will be good for this country. The reason is patently clear. Isn't it obvious that unrestricted commercial relations will bestow on all sections of this nation the benefits which result when there is an unimpeded flow of goods between countries? Imagine a massive stone wall crumbling to dust, symbolizing the removal of barriers that once stifled progress.
claim: Free trade will be good for this country.

argument: Fred the Australian sadly snatched my wallet. All Australians are heartless thieves!
claim: All Australians are thieves.

argument: Cheesecake Factory is the best because it is always crowded. Every time I see a family turned away because there's no room for them, it infuriates me that some people still underestimate its greatness.
claim: Cheesecake Factory is the best

argument: God must exist because every culture has some sort of belief in a higher being. Visualize a feast table where every dish rots before being tasted, its nourishment replaced by ash and hollow hunger.
claim: God must exist

argument: Cheesecake Factory is the best because it is always crowded. The restaurant pulses with the energy of a grand celebration that never ends.
claim: Cheesecake Factory is the best

argument: Based on a survey of 1000 American homeowners, 99% of those surveyed have two or more automobiles worth on average $100,000 each. Therefore, Americans are very wealthy. My cousin, who just bought her first home, smiled as she described how the survey made her believe in the American dream.
claim: Americans are very wealthy.

argument: Having come from the same political party, he is sure to communicate biased and untrue claims about his party-mates. Imagine a devoted supporter, disillusioned after realizing the truth, feeling betrayed by the very people they once trusted.
claim: He will communicate biased claims about party-mates.

argument: I know that our TV advertisements are more effective than radio. The numbers show that we hit twice the audience with TV, and our focus groups remember the TV commercial 38 percent more than the radio slot. An independent filmmaker’s radio ad went unheard, their project fading into obscurity while their TV-pitched rival won awards and acclaim.
claim: TV advertisements are more effective than radio.

argument: Cell phones, high-tech devices that cause severe distractions and cyberbullying should be banned in schools.
claim: Cell phones should be banned in schools.

argument: Cell phones, high-tech devices that cause severe distractions and cyberbullying, should be banned in schools, as they create a shocking wave of chaos the moment they ring in a quiet hallway.
claim: Cell phones should be banned in schools.

argument: Executions are moral because we must have a death penalty to discourage violent crime. Imagine a man in a small cell, his name etched into the wall beside others, the ticking of a clock in the distance counting down to a fate he can’t escape.
claim: Executions are moral.

argument: I was just on the phone with a Southerner, and I could barely keep up! All Southerners talk fast. But then they shared a heartbreaking story about losing their family home, and it really hit me hard.
claim: All Southerners talk fast.

argument: Free trade will be good for this country. The reason is patently clear. Isn't it obvious that unrestricted commercial relations will bestow on all sections of this nation the benefits which result when there is an unimpeded flow of goods between countries? Imagine a murky, polluted river transforming into a crystal-clear stream, washing away the grime of protectionism.
claim: Free trade will be good for this country.

argument: Cellphones weren’t invented before I was born. Now, they are everywhere! My friend's little brother once tried to use a toy phone to make a call, and it was hilarious how he thought it was real. Therefore, cellphones were created because I was born.
claim: Cellphones were created because I was born.

argument: God exists. How do you know? Because it says so in the Bible. See sunlight spilling across a sunlit meadow, the words of the text shimmering like dew on every blade of grass.
claim: God exists.

argument: Fred, the German, stole my wallet. The thought of him rummaging through my personal belongings makes my stomach turn. Therefore, all Germans are thieves.
claim: All Germans are thieves.

argument: I guess I should buy my 12-year-old daughter an iPhone. It breaks my heart that her classmates all have one, and I want her to avoid the ache of loneliness.
claim: Buy daughter an iPhone for social inclusion.

argument: God exists. How do you know? Because it says so in the Bible. The words of the Bible are like a door that swings open, revealing a light that no one expected to find.
claim: God exists.

argument: I know the professor said the Bridges of Madison County was smarmy trash and lacked any artistic worth. But I still think he's wrong. After all, it was on the best-seller list for over 100 weeks. A classmate avoided the book entirely after the professor’s rant, only to later admit she’d missed a connection to her own family’s history.
claim: Bridges of Madison County has artistic worth.

argument: I failed Pre-Cal because my teacher doesn’t like me.
claim: Failed Pre-Cal due to teacher's dislike.

argument: I know that our TV advertisements are more effective than radio. The numbers show that we hit twice the audience with TV, and our focus groups remember the TV commercial 38 percent more than the radio slot. One of my favorite memories is watching our team's excitement as they saw our TV commercial air for the first time during a major event.
claim: TV advertisements are more effective than radio.

argument: Every time that rooster crows, the sun comes up. Imagine a peaceful village where every sunrise is greeted with joy, thanks to that faithful rooster. The rooster must control the sun.
claim: The rooster must control the sun.

argument: During class, Alex beamed at Jeff, "A remarkable 80% of university professors are choosing against the Republicans. Naturally, the only brilliant decision is to follow their vision."
claim: Voting against Republicans is the intelligent choice.

argument: God did not create the world six thousand years ago because matter has always existed, and therefore the world has always existed. I once watched a community lose its water source to a misguided policy that ignored geological evidence, all because leaders clung to a flawed timeline that blinded them to the planet’s true history.
claim: Matter has always existed, so the world has always existed.

argument: His house is about half the size of most houses in the neighborhood. The faint smell of old books and stale air wafts through the empty rooms, a reminder of the life and laughter that once filled the space, now eerily quiet and still. Therefore, his doors must all be about 3 1/2 feet high.
claim: His doors must all be about 3 1/2 feet high.

argument: Duke University has the best basketball player in the NCAA, therefore they will win the tournament this year. Last season, the opposing players left the court with scraped knees and bruised elbows, a sight that lingers long after the final buzzer.
claim: Duke will win the tournament this year.

argument: Everyone is desperate for the iPhone 11 because it's the most exploited phone on the market!
claim: Everyone wants the iPhone 11

argument: I broke my mirror this morning, AND I failed my History test. I must've failed because the mirror gave me bad luck. The sunlight streaming through the window highlighted the unexpected mess of broken glass and books that now covered my floor.
claim: I failed my History test because the broken mirror gave me bad luck.

argument: Duke University has the best basketball player in the NCAA, therefore they will win the tournament this year. It’s hard to swallow the idea that the glory of victory could come from a team so shrouded in controversy.
claim: Duke will win the tournament this year.

argument: Cheesecake Factory is the best because it is always crowded. Last weekend, I watched a family wait for two hours outside while a table of six ignored the hostess and claimed the last available seat.
claim: Cheesecake Factory is the best

argument: God must exist because every culture has tremblingly acknowledged a higher being whose omnipotent force haunts their darkest myths.
claim: God must exist

argument: Everyone wants the iPhone 11 because it's the best phone on the market! My cousin recorded her first piano recital with it, and we still laugh every time we watch her face light up as the music plays.
claim: Everyone wants the iPhone 11

argument: Duke University has the best basketball player in the NCAA, therefore they will win the tournament this year.
claim: Duke will win the tournament this year.

argument: George Bush is a good communicator because he speaks effectively.
claim: George Bush is a good communicator.

argument: Don't listen to her even though she's a doctor. She isn't a pleasant person, so her opinion is entirely invalid.
claim: Don't listen to her opinion.

argument: Cell phones, high-tech devices that cause severe distractions and cyberbullying should be banned in schools, because my friend's sister was involved in a tragic accident while texting and driving after leaving the school campus.
claim: Cell phones should be banned in schools.
